holdings.text: An order under s. 25A decides only whether there has been a partition and the shares therein, and has no effect on the assessment of income under s. 23.

anchor.surface_text: in the proceedings under s. 25A, the Income-tax Officer had held, after making enquiry, that the partition set up by it was true, and that as that order had become final, it must conclude the present question

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25A introduced to prevent tax escape on division by deeming family undivided until order; limits enquiry to partition fact and portions; income quantum under s.23 separate proceeding.

holdings.text: The s.25A order does not expressly or impliedly decide that the family possessed jewels listed in Ex.A or converted them to cash; same officer's same-day s.23 order rejects that.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the order of the Income-tax Officer under s. 25A, it was not open to the Department to contend that the sum of Rs. 2,30,346 does not represent

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express finding; implied finding impossible given scope of s.25A and contemporaneous contrary s.23 finding by same officer.

holdings.text: The Appellate Tribunal did not act perversely or unreasonably in refusing to admit the proceedings book in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts, we are unable to hold that in refusing to admit the proceedings book as evidence in the appeal, the Appellate Tribunal acted perversely

holdings.reasoning_summary: Book not proved to be same produced before ITO; prior minutes not shown, translated or relied on before ITO or AAC; no reference in assessment order.

holdings.text: The finding that Rs. 2,30,346 represents undisclosed business profits is supported by evidence and not perverse.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, counsel for the appellant did not contend in the High Court that the Tribunal had acted illegally or unreasonably in refusing to admit the proceedings book in evidence. That being so, it cannot be said that the finding given by the Tribunal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence before ITO (accounts discrepancies, weight diff, round figures, no jewel list/accounts, changing explanations) sufficient; proceedings book irrelevant as not relied before; no perversity.

holdings.text: Where assessee fails to prove source and nature of cash credits, ITO entitled to infer they are assessable business receipts; applied here.

anchor.surface_text: That is precisely what the Income-tax authorities have done in the present case, and we do not find any grounds for holding that their finding is open to attack

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent (Govindarajulu Mudaliar); appellant's jewel sale explanation rejected on facts; credits treated as business income taxable including under Excess Profits Tax Act.

holdings.text: No levy issue under Excess Profits Tax Act as authorities found credits to be business profits/receipts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior finding of concealed business profits suffices; no separate finding needed.
